revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1573|music}}
== Events == * Approximate formation date of the [[Florentine Camerata]], at the salon of Count Giovanni de' Bardi (earliest record is January 14, 1573). *[[Manuel Rodrigues Coelho]] becomes organist of [[Badajoz Cathedral]].
== Publications ==
* [[Cipriano de Rore]], ''Sacrae cantiones'' (pub. by [[Pierre Phalèse]])
== Births ==
*[[January 31]] **[[Ambrosius Metzger]], German composer and [[Meistersinger]] **[[Giulio Cesare Monteverdi]] (baptized), Italian composer, younger brother of [[Claudio Monteverdi]] *[[February 22]] – [[Gemignano Capilupi]], Italian composer *[[July 19]] (baptized) – [[Inigo Jones]], English stage designer and architect (died 1652) *''date unknown'' **[[Francesco Colombini]], Italian composer and organist **[[Benedikt Faber]], German composer **[[Juan de Palomares]], Spanish composer and guitarist **[[Alessandro Striggio (ii)|Alessandro Striggio]] the younger, Italian composer *''probable'' – [[Géry de Ghersem]], Flemish composer and singer (died 1630) ** [[Cesarina Ricci de Tingoli]], Italian composer.
== Deaths == *[[March 15]] (or earlier) – [[Christopher Tye]], English composer (born c1505) *[[November 17]] – [[Joannes Pionnier]], French composer *[[December 7]] – John Thorne, English composer and poet *[[December 27]]–[[December 31]] – [[Firmin Lebel]], French chorus director and composer *''date unknown'' **[[Johannes Claux]], Flemish composer **[[Melchior Kreisstein]], German music printer **[[Gislain Manilius]], Flemish music printer **[[Pierre Phalèse the Elder]], Flemish music publisher *''probable'' – [[Alfonso dalla Viola]], Italian composer and instrumentalist
[[Category:1573|Music]] [[Category:16th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

Tora!|accessdate=January 9, 2012}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| '''9.''' |''[[Chariots of the Gods (film)|Chariots of the Gods]]'' | [[Constantin Film]] / [[Sunn Classic Pictures]] | $25,948,300{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldwideboxoffice.com/movie.cgi?title=Erinnerungen%20an%20die%20Zukunft&year=1970|website=Worldwide Box Office|title=Chariots of the Gods, Worldwide Box Office Information|accessdate=January 9, 2012}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| '''10.''' | ''[[The Aristocats]]'' | [[Walt Disney Productions]] | $20,222,599$55,675,257 Lifetime gross {{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Aristocats-The#tab=box-office|website=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|title=The Aristocats Box Office Data|accessdate=April 9, 2018}}
$35,452,658 reissue grosses {{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/search/?q=aristocats|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|title=The Aristocats|accessdate=June 11, 2018}} |} ==Events== * January 9 - [[Larry Fine]], the second member of [[The Three Stooges]], suffers a massive stroke, effectively ending his career. * February 11 - ''[[The Magic Christian (film)|The Magic Christian]]'', starring [[Peter Sellers]] and [[Ringo Starr]], premieres in New York City. The film's soundtrack album, including [[Badfinger]]'s "Come and Get It" (written and produced by [[Paul McCartney]]), is released on [[Apple Records]]. * March 12 - Film debut of [[Ornella Muti]] in ''[[La moglie più bella]]'' (The Most Beautiful Wife) 3 days after her 15th birthday.IMDB * March 17 - The controversial film ''[[The Boys in the Band]]'', directed by [[William Friedkin]] and based on [[Mart Crowley]]'s hit off-Broadway play, opens in theaters. *October 24 - [[Joan Crawford]]'s final film, the low-budget horror picture ''[[Trog]]'', opens in theaters. * The [[IMAX]] motion picture projection system premieres at the Fuji Pavilion, at [[Expo '70]] in [[Osaka, Japan]]. * In [[Culver City, California]], [[MGM]] begins selling off its studio back lot property and movie props. ==Awards== '''[[43rd Academy Awards|Academy Awards]]:''' :[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]: '''''[[Patton (film)|Patton]]''''' - 20th Century Fox :[[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]]: [[Darryl F. Zanuck]] accepting on behalf of '''[[Franklin J. Schaffner]]''' - ''Patton'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: Darryl F. Zanuck accepting on behalf of '''[[George C. Scott]]''' - ''Patton'' (declined) :[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: [[Anne Francis]] accepting on behalf of '''[[Glenda Jackson]]''' - ''[[Women in Love (film)|Women in Love]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]: [[Juliet Mills]] accepting on behalf of '''[[John Mills]]''' - ''[[Ryan's Daughter]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]: [[Angela Lansbury]] accepting on behalf of '''[[Helen Hayes]]''' - ''[[Airport (1970 film)|Airport]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]]: '''''[[Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion]]''''' (''Indagine su un cittadino al di sopra di ogni sospetto''), directed by [[Elio Petri]], Italy '''[[28th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]]:''' :'''Drama:''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Picture]]: '''''[[Love Story (1970 film)|Love Story]]''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor]]: '''[[George C. Scott]]''' – ''Patton'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actress]]: '''[[Ali MacGraw]]''' – ''Love Story'' :'''Musical or comedy:''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Picture]]: '''''[[MASH (film)|MASH]]''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor]]: '''[[Albert Finney]]''' – ''[[Scrooge (1970 film)|Scrooge]]'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress]]: '''[[Carrie Snodgress]]''' – ''[[Diary of a Mad Housewife]]'' :'''Other''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Director – Motion Picture|Best Director]]: '''[[Arthur Hiller]]''', ''Love Story'' '''[[1970 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]] (Palme d'Or):''' :'''''MASH''''', directed by [[Robert Altman]], United States ==Notable films released in 1970== [[American films of 1970|U.S.A.]] unless stated '''#''' *''[[7 Plus Seven]]'', a TV documentary directed by [[Michael Apted]] - revision.text:
[[File:AVAF LOGO.png|right|thumb|[http://www.addisvideoartfestival.net/]]]
'''Addis Video Art [[Festival]]''' is an annual international [[video art]] [[festival]] in [[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopia]].
Addis Video Art Festival intends to provide a platform for innovative video art in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The festival will screen throughout the city in a variety of locations including street corners, rooftops, public centers and art centers. By sharing video art in both conventional and non-conventional settings, the festival will reach both the artist community and the everyday passerby. The festival aims to create a dialogue between local, and international artists by promoting and encouraging [[digital media]] culture.
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.addisvideoartfestival.net|title=Addis Video Art Festival}}</ref><ref>New York Foundation for the Arts Currents: http://current.nyfa.org/post/138222314348/iap-archive-ezra-wube</ref><ref>The Reporter: http://www.thereporterethiopia.com/content/disrupting-normal-scene-through-videos{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>Contemporary And: http://www.contemporaryand.com/fr/magazines/new-home/</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.addisvideoartfestival.net/index.htm Official website]
[[Category:Addis Ababa]] [[Category:Art festivals in Africa]]

[[File:Anonymous Romanesque aquamanile in the form of a lion.jpg|thumb|Brass aquamanile in the form of a lion from [[Lower Saxony]] or [[Westphalia]], Germany, 13th century ([[National Museum, Warsaw|National Museum]] in [[Warsaw]])]] In modern usage, an '''aquamanile''' (plural '''aquamanilia''' or simply '''aquamaniles''') is a [[ewer]] or [[Jug (container)|jug]]-type vessel in the form of one or more animal or human figures. It usually contained water for the washing of hands (''aqua'' + ''manos'') over a basin, which was part of both upper-class meals and the Christian [[Eucharist]]. Historically the term was sometimes used for any shape of basin or ewer so used, regardless of shape. Most surviving examples are in metal, typically [[copper alloy]]s ([[brass]] or [[bronze]]), as pottery versions have rarely survived.
==Islamic art== Persian aquamaniles predate any zoomorphic aquamaniles known in Europe. An Iranian (Abbasid caliphate), Aquamanile in the form of an eagle, bearing the date 180 AH/CE 796-797, of bronze, inlaid with silver and copper, in the [[State Hermitage Museum]], St. Petersburg, is the earliest dated Islamic object in metalwork.<ref>Piotrovsky M.B. and Rogers, J.M. (eds), ''Heaven on Earth: Art from Islamic Lands'', pp. 80-81, 2004, Prestel, {{ISBN|3791330551}}</ref> Among the latest in date is one also at the State Hermitage Museum, a late Islamic aquamanile from [[greater Khorasan|Khorasan]], dated 1206.<ref>Piotrovsky M.B. and Rogers, J.M. (eds), ''Heaven on Earth: Art from Islamic Lands'', p. 89, 2004, Prestel, {{ISBN|3791330551}}</ref> [[Aniconism in Islam|Islamic law deprecated]] the use of such representational figures, and the Islamic zoomorphic aquamanile tradition died out.
However the tradition was taken up enthusiastically in Europe, where the form remained popular until the Renaissance.
==Europe== [[File:Aquamanile in the Form of a Lion MET DP117252.jpg|thumb|left|''Aquamanile in the Form of a Lion'', [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Aquamanile_in_the_Form_of_a_Lion_MET_DP117252.jpg Metropolitan Museum of Art]]] [[File:Equestrian Knight Aquamanile.jpg|thumb|upright|Bronze aquamanile in the form of a mounted knight, second half of the 13th century, [[Lower Saxony]] ([[Metropolitan Museum of Art]])]] The [[Byzantine Empire]]'s cultural connections with [[Sassanid|Sassanid Persia]] and the [[Abbasid]] caliphate, never peaceful in the political sphere, nevertheless brought the aquamanile into the Christian Mediterranean world. The earliest European portable aquamaniles date to the eleventh century. Ewers and basins were needed in [[Christian liturgy]] for the ritual of the [[lavabo]], in which the officiating priest washes his hands before vesting, again before the consecration of the Eucharist and after mass. As a ritual object, metal was considered more suitable than pottery, although most examples in pottery no doubt were broken and discarded. The aquamaniles made in the [[Mosan art|Mosan]] – or [[Meuse]] valley – region, using the [[brass]] alloy of silvery tint called ''dinanderie'' (from the center of its manufacture in the region of [[Dinant]]) were often fantastic and zoomorphic in their forms, which were constrained only by the need for a larger opening for filling the vessel and a spout for pouring. Church records inventory aquamaniles in silver or gilt copper, but the great majority of surviving examples are in base metals, which were not worth melting down.
[[File:Aguamanil medieval paloma (M.A.N. Inv.2005-72-1) 01.jpg|thumb|upright|left|An 11–12th century [[Islamic art|Islamic]] aquamanile from [[Iran]], later used in liturgy by [[Spain in the Middle Ages|Medieval Spanish]] Christians ([[National Archaeological Museum of Spain|M.A.N.]], [[Madrid]])]] [[File:Aquamanile Aachener Domschatz.jpg|thumb|Aquamanile, about 1170/80, ([[Aachen Cathedral Treasury]])]]
As well as the altar, aquamaniles were used at the tables of the great, where extravagant designs of symbolic or fantastical beasts – lions were especially popular – were developed in purely secular [[iconography]]. A gold aquamanile, c. 1215, in the treasury of the [[Aachen Cathedral|cathedral]] at [[Aachen]], takes the form of a man's bust; it is a rare survival of an aquamanile in a precious metal. An aquamanile (ref. Metropolitan Museum) in the form of [[Aristotle]] on hands and knees, being ridden by Phyllis, bore several moral lessons, with ribald undertones; such an aquamanile was distinctly secular in nature.
Bronze aquamaniles in the form of leopards were part of court ritual in [[Benin]], where the concept may have arrived from the Islamic north. An 18th-century bronze leopard aquamanile from Benin is in the collection of the [[Minneapolis Institute of Arts]].
From the Renaissance elaborate versions of the conventional ewer were preferred to zoomorphic forms. A late version of the aquamanile was the silver-gilt mounted rider on a stand, bought in 1700 for the treasury of the [[Basilica of St-Denis]] and sold in 1798. Its form is recorded in an engraving by Félibien. (ref. St-Denis) The idea of [[ewer]]s in fantastic shapes has never died out.
==Examples== [[File:Aquamanile Aristotle’s lay 5.jpg|thumb|''Aquamanile Aristotle and Phyllis'' ([[Musée Dobrée]], [[Nantes]], [[France]])]]
The following aquamanilia in public collections are set in approximate chronological order: *[http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_5_5b.html State Hermitage Museum, Aquamanile in the form of an eagle, signed by "Suleiman" dated 180 AH/796-797] *[http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/03/hm3_5_5c.html State Hermitage Museum, aquamanile of a cow with her calf, Khorasan, dated CE 1206]; the handle is in the form of a lion, attacking the cow by the hump of its back. *[http://www.personal.kent.edu/~rlokay/British/page11.html Victoria and Albert Museum, Aquamanile in the form of a griffin, ca 1130] *[http://www.nga.gov/collection/gallery/medieval/medieval-1447.0.html National Gallery of Art, Washington, Aquamanile in the form of a lion, bronze with traces of gilding, North French or Mosan, c 1300]*[http://www.nga.gov/collection/gallery/medieval/medieval-1446.0.html National Gallery of Art, Washington DC, Aquamanile in the form of a mounted horseman, English or Scandinavian, 13th century] *[http://www.rijksmuseum.nl/aria/aria_assets/BK-NM-14111?lang=en Rijksmuseum, Aquamanile in the form of a horse, bronze, Maas/Meuse region, 13th century] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928021713/http://www.wartburg-eisenach.de/english/museum/aquamanile.htm Wartburg, Eisenach, Aquamanile in the form of a lion, 13th century] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/crus/ho_64.101.1492.htm Metropolitan Museum of Art, Aquamanile in the form of a mounted knight, bronze, Lower Saxony, late 13th century] *[http://legionofhonor.famsf.org Legion of Honor,San Francisco, Aquamnile of a lion, German, 13th century] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/viewone.asp?dep=15&viewmode=0&item=1975%2E1%2E1416 Metropolitan Museum of Art, Aquamanile in the form of Aristotle and Phyllis, Lorraine, c 1400] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/Works_of_Art/viewOne.asp?dep=7&viewMode=0&item=1994%2E244 The Cloisters Collection, Aquamanile in the form of a lion, copper alloy, Nuremberg, c 1400] *[http://www.rijksmuseum.nl/aria/aria_assets/BK-16912?lang=en Rijksmuseum, Aquamanile in the form of a lion, last quarter of the 14th century] *[http://vrcoll.fa.pitt.edu/medart/menufrance/sdenis/treasure/FelePl2/PlateII-p.html "The Treasure of Saint Denis"] * Circa 1665, ''Aquamanile Shaped like a Rider'' from [[Augsburg]], Germany ([[Hermitage Museum]]).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/fcgi-bin/db2www/descrPage.mac/descrPage?selLang=English&indexClass=GLASSWARE_EN&PID=J-7411&numView=1&ID_NUM=3|title=Aquamanile Shaped like a Rider |work=Hermitage Museum}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bartmann jug]]s, also known as ''Bellarmine jubs'', pottery jugs with bearded faces manufactured in Europe in 16th and 17th centuries. * [[Toby jug]], pottery jug in the form of a seated person, or the head. * [[Cow creamer]], ceramic or silver cream dispenser in the shape of a cow.
==References== *Legner, Anton (ed). ''Ornamenta Ecclesiae, Kunst und Künstler der Romanik.'' Catalogue of an exhibition in the Schnütgen Museum, Köln, 1985. 3 vols.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{Cite book |last1=Barnet |first1=Peter |last2=Dandridge |first2=Pete |year=2006 |title=Lions, Dragons, & other Beasts: Aquamanilia of the Middle Ages: Vessels for Church and Table |others=(Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design & Culture) |publisher=Yale University Press |isbn=978-0-300-11684-7|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |first1=Elizabeth S. |last1=Ettinghausen|editor=Jens Kröger |editor2=Annette Hagedorn |editor3=Avinoam Shalem |title=Facts and artefacts: art in the Islamic |volume=68 |series=Islamic history and civilization: Studies and texts |publisher=Brill |year=2007 |isbn=978-90-04-15782-8 |chapter=Analysing a Pictorial Narrative The Aquamanile in the Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg|ref=harv}} * {{Cite book |chapter=About a bronze bird |first=Oleg |last=Grabar |year=2002 |title=Reading medieval images : the art historian and the object |editor1-first= Elizabeth |editor1-last=Sears |editor2-first=Thelma K. |editor2-last=Thomas |location=Ann Arbor |publisher=University of Michigan Press |isbn= 0-472-09751-2 |pages=117–125}} * {{Cite journal|language=German|title=Das Aquamanile der "rotbemalten Feinware" aus Speyer |last=Gross |first=Uwe |year=1983 |journal=Pfälzer Heimat |volume=4/1983 |pages=145–155 |url=http://archiv.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/artdok/volltexte/2009/666/ }}
==External links== *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/66219/rec/1 European sculpture and metalwork], a collection catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on aquamanile (see index) {{commons category|Aquamanile}}

{{Infobox library | library_name = Archives of Traditional Music | library_logo = Logo-ATM.png | logo_alt = olive green square; the top half is alternating diagonal darker and light olive green wavy lines, the lower half contains the words Archives of Traditional Music written in light olive against a darker olive background | image = Sarah Parke Morrison Hall, Indiana University.jpg | alt = Panoramic view of Morrison Hall | caption = Morrison Hall, current home of the Archives | location = [[Bloomington, IN]], [[United States|U.S.]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|09|55|N|86|31|11|W|region:US-IN_type:landmark_scale:10000|display=inline,title}} | established = {{start date and age|1954}} | num_branches = N/A | collection_size = More than 100,000 recordings including nearly 7000 [[wax cylinders]], 4600 [[Acetate disc|lacquer discs]], 2625 [[aluminum disc]]s, 250 [[Wire recording|wires]], 18,000 [[Reel-to-reel audio tape recording|open reel tapes]], 7500 [[Compact Cassette|audiocassettes]], 911 films, and 1500 video recordings. The Archives holds over 2700 collections of [[field recording]]s and over 24,300 commercial recordings.<ref name="Collections">{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~libarchm/index.php/atm-collections.html/ |title=Collections|publisher=Archives of Traditional Music |accessdate=2018-03-22}}</ref> | annual_circulation = Archives do not publicly circulate | pop_served = 48,514 faculty, staff, and students at [[Indiana University Bloomington]], additional scholars, and members of the public | director = Alan Burdette | website = [http://www.indiana.edu/~libarchm/index.php/ indiana.edu/~libarchm/] }}
The [[Indiana University]] '''Archives of Traditional Music''' holds over 100,000 audio and video individual recordings across over 3500 collections of field, broadcast, and commercial recordings. Its holdings are primarily focused on audiovisual recordings relating to research in the academic disciplines of [[ethnomusicology]], [[folklore]], [[anthropology]], [[linguistics]], and various area studies.
==History== The archive was initiated by [[George Herzog]] at [[Columbia University]] in 1936. It was modeled on the [[Berliner Phonogramm-Archiv]], where Herzog had worked as an assistant to [[Erich von Hornbostel|Erich M. von Hornbostel]] from 1921–1924. Herzog brought the nascent archive to [[Indiana University]] in 1948 when he was appointed as professor in the Department of Anthropology. The archive was formally established at Indiana University in 1954 under its second director, [[George List]], as the Archives of Folk and Primitive Music. Its present name, the Archives of Traditional Music, was adopted in 1964 when it became a division of the Folklore Institute.<ref name="ATM Booklet">{{cite book|title=Archives of Traditional Music Folklore Institute|date=1970|publisher=Indiana University Archives of Traditional Music Folklore Institute|location=Bloomington, IN|page=1}}</ref>
===Directors=== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Date!!Name!!class="unsortable"|Notes |- |1948–1954||data-sort-value="Herzog, George"|[[George Herzog (ethnomusicologist)|George Herzog]]|| |- |1954–1977||data-sort-value="List, George"|[[George List]]|| |- |1977–1981||data-sort-value="Gillis, Frank"|[[Frank Gillis]]|| |- |1981–1982||data-sort-value="Smith, Ronald"|Ronald Smith||Acting Director |- |1982–1988||data-sort-value="Seeger, Anthony"|Anthony Seeger|| |- |1988–1995||data-sort-value="Stone, Ruth M."|Ruth M. Stone|| |- |1995–2000||data-sort-value="Gibson, Gloria J."|Gloria J. Gibson|| |- |2000–2002||data-sort-value="Stone, Ruth M."|Ruth M. Stone||Interim Director |- |2002–2007||data-sort-value="Reed, Daniel"|Daniel Reed|| |- |2007–Present||data-sort-value="Burdette, Alan"|Alan Burdette|| |}
==Facilities== [[File:Archives of Traditional Music Vault.jpg|thumb|A shelf in the vault]] * Listening Library * Reading Room * Hoagy Carmichael Room * Studios * Vault: A 2,138 square foot temperature- and humidity-controlled storage space. Many formats of materials are kept in the vault, including 7000 wax cylinders, 4600 lacquer discs, 2625 aluminum discs, 250 wires, 18,000 open reel tapes, 7500 audiocassettes, 911 films, and 1500 video recordings. Nearly half of the recordings are unique field recordings that document the expressive culture and languages of peoples around the world.
==Holdings on the [[National Recording Registry]]== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Year Inducted!!Title!!Composer/Recorder!!Year Recorded!!class="unsortable"|Notes |- |2017||[[Standing Rock Indian Reservation|Standing Rock]] Reservation Recordings|| data-sort-value="Herzog, George" |[[Dakota people|Yanktonai-Dakota]] singers recorded by [[George Herzog (ethnomusicologist)|George Herzog]] ||1928||Field recordings on 195 [[phonograph cylinder]]s |- |2013||Songs sung by [[Kwakwaka'wakw]] (Kwakiutl) Chief Dan Cranmer|| data-sort-value="Cranmer, Dan" |[[Franz Boas]] and [[George Herzog (ethnomusicologist)|George Herzog]], Interviewers||1938||Field recordings on 22 [[aluminum disc]]s |- |2006||Interviews with William "Billy" Bell, representing the [[Edward D. Ives]] Collection||data-sort-value="Bell, William"|William "Billy" Bell recorded by [[Edward D. Ives|Edward D. ("Sandy") Ives]]||1928||Field recordings on 28 [[Reel-to-reel audio tape recording|open reel tapes]]; (other recordings also held at Maine Folklife Center, [[University of Maine]]) |- |2005||Listen to the Lambs (single)||data-sort-value=”Hampton Quartet”|Hampton Quartette, recorded by [[Natalie Curtis|Natalie Curtis Burlin]]||1917||Field recording in a collection of 15 [[phonograph cylinder]]s |- |2004||[[Stardust (song)|Stardust (single)]]||data-sort-value="Carmichael, Hoagy"|[[Hoagy Carmichael]]||1927||Pop, pre-1955; manuscript held in the archive |- |2004||Rosina Cohen oral narrative from the [[Lorenzo Dow Turner]] Collection||data-sort-value="Cohen, Rosina"|Rosina Cohen, [[Lorenzo Dow Turner|Lorenzo D. Turner]]||1932||Field recording in a collection of 154 [[aluminum disc]] recordings from the U.S. [[Sea Islands]] |- |2003||[[Guy Benton Johnson|Johnson (Guy B.)]] Cylinder recordings of African-American music||data-sort-value="Johnson, Guy B."|[[Guy Benton Johnson|Guy B. Johnson]]||1920s||Field recordings on 8 [[phonograph cylinder]]s |}
==Preservation== Following insights gained through the Sound Directions Project about a looming crisis in time-based media preservation, staff at the ATM pursued a collaborative strategy for saving its media holdings. In 2008, they participated in a small coalition of archivists and librarians at Indiana University that began a survey of the audio-visual materials held on the Bloomington Campus. The survey was prompted by the recognition that the university held a large amount of time-based media in danger of deterioration and playback obsolescence. This survey revealed that the Bloomington campus held more than a half-million audiovisual recordings across eighty units and that large portions of the University's holdings were at risk for loss. Following the publication of a survey report in 2009, the Office of the Vice Provost for Research funded a preservation planning document under the aegis of what was known as the Media Preservation Initiative (MPI).<ref name="Media Preservation Initiative">{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~libarchm/index.php/projects/media-preservation-initiative.html|title=MPI|publisher=Indiana University Archive of Traditional Music|accessdate=2018-04-05}}</ref> Based on the recommendations of the planning document, Indiana University President Michael McRobbie announced a 15 million dollar commitment to the preservation of audio and video recordings on the Bloomington campus. The resulting endeavor was renamed the Media Preservation and Digitization Initiative (MDPI) which formed a partnership with Memnon Archiving Services to digitally preserve 280,000 audio and video recordings by 2020.<ref name="Media Digitization and Preservation Initiative">{{cite web |url=https://mdpi.iu.edu/index.php |title=MDPI|publisher=Media and Digitization and Preservation Initiative |accessdate=2018-04-05}}</ref> In 2017, 12,000 films from Indiana University's Moving Image Archives and other campus collections, including the Archives of Traditional Music were added to the efforts of MDPI. As the largest holder of unique and rare audiovisual recordings at Indiana University, nearly all of the archives' 100,000 recordings will be digitized by 2020 through this initiative. MDPI was the first – and as of 2018 the only – university-based media preservation effort in the United States on this scale.
==Projects==
===Archive of Historical and Ethnographic Yiddish Memories=== The AHEYM Project has collected nearly 400 interviews related to Jewish life before, during, and after World War II. Conducted primarily in Yiddish, the interviewees come from small towns throughout Ukraine, Moldova, Romania, Hungary and Slovakia. The current online exhibit cover daily life, foodways, Jewish life between the wars, religion, World War II and the Holocaust, and Jewish life after World War II. The archive can be explored by location, person, or subject.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iub.edu/~aheym/index.php|title=AHEYM - The Archives of Historical and Ethnographic Yiddish Memories - Home - Indiana University|website=www.iub.edu}}</ref> Preservation and cataloging of AHEYM Project recordings was funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
===Ethnographic Video for Instruction and Analysis (EVIA) Digital Archive=== The EVIA Digital Archive is a project created to host a digital archive of ethnographic videos for educational use. The projected originated from a collaboration between Indiana University and University of Michigan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eviada.webhost.iu.edu/Scripts/default.cfm|title=EVIA Digital Archive Project|publisher=Ethnographic Video for Instruction and Analysis (EVIA) Digital Archive|accessdate=2018-04-25}}</ref>
===Ethnomusicology Multimedia=== EM publishes books and supplemental audiovisual material on [[Ethnomusicology]] in order to aid scholars in research. EM offers access to Annotation Management System (AMS), which allows authors to upload audiovisual material and link it to content in their text. EM is a joint project between Indiana and Temple Universities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ethnomultimedia.org/about.html|title=About Ethnomusicology Online|website=ethnomultimedia.org}}</ref>
===Hoagy Carmichael Online=== The [[Hoagy Carmichael]] Project at [[Indiana University]] was a project funded by IMLS between 1999 and 2000 to digitize and preserve the extensive collection of items related to Hoagy Carmichael that are housed at Indiana University. This early digital collection website aimed to present in its entirety the complete Carmichael collection. The collection contains sound recordings, letters, photographs, lyric sheets, correspondence, as well as personal effects. It offers a biography and a virtual tour of the Carmichael Room located at the Archives of Traditional Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dlib.indiana.edu/collections/hoagy/intro/collec_over/|title=Overview of the Hoagy Carmichael Collection|website=www.dlib.indiana.edu}}</ref>
===Liberian Collections Project=== The Liberian Collection was established in 2002. The Archives of Traditional Music is home to the audiovisual part of the collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://guides.libraries.indiana.edu/africanstudies/liberia|title=Library Research Guides: African Studies Research Guide: Liberian Collections|first=Mireille|last=Djenno|website=guides.libraries.indiana.edu}}</ref>
===Sound Directions=== The Sound Directions Project was a joint project between Indiana University’s Archives of Traditional Music and Harvard University’s Archive of World Music and funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities between 2005 and 2011. Phase 1 consisted of testing and determining the best practices and workflows for digital audio preservation. The following two phases focused on the preservation of archive holdings and on the development of software tools for media assessment and technical metadata collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dlib.indiana.edu/projects/sounddirections/|title=Sound Directions: Digital Audio Preservation and Access for Global Audio Heritage|website=www.dlib.indiana.edu}}</ref>
==Publications== * ''ReSound'' (quarterly) {{ISSN|0749-2472}}; OCLC: 10204552. Issues are available online at [https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/handle/2022/21233/ IU ScholarWorks] * ''Folklore and Folk Music Archivist'' {{ISSN|0430-8840}}; OCLC: 1569577. Issues are available online at [https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/handle/2022/706/ IU ScholarWorks]

<!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Indian cities]] for details -->{{Infobox settlement | name = Basohli | native_name = | native_name_lang = | other_name =Basohli,Basoli | nickname = Basohli | settlement_type = Town | image_skyline = | image_alt = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = India Jammu and Kashmir#India | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Jammu and Kashmir, India | coordinates = {{coord|32.50|N|75.82|E|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{flag|India}} | subdivision_type1 = [[States and territories of India|State]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Jammu and Kashmir]] | subdivision_type2 = [[List of districts of India|District]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Kathua district|Kathua]] | established_title = <!-- Established --> | established_date = | founder = | named_for = | government_type = | governing_body = | unit_pref = Metric | area_footnotes = | area_rank = | area_total_km2 = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = 1200 | population_total = 1 | population_as_of = 2014 | population_rank = | population_density_km2 = auto | population_demonym = | population_footnotes = | demographics_type1 = Languages | demographics1_title1 = Official | demographics1_info1 = [[Dogri]] [[Hindi]] | timezone1 = [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] | utc_offset1 = +5:30 | postal_code_type = <!-- [[Postal Index Number|PIN]] --> | postal_code = 184201 | registration_plate = | website = www.basohli.in/www.pinglamata.org | footnotes = }}
[[File:Ganesha Basohli miniature circa 1730 Dubost p73.jpg|thumb|[[Ganesha]] (ca. 1730).<ref>National Museum, New Delhi. For description of the work see: Martin-Dubost (1997), p. 73, which says: "Ganesha getting ready to throw his lotus. Basohli miniature, circa 1730. National Museum, New Delhi. Attired in an orange dhoti, his body is enitirely red. On the three points of his tiny crown, budding lotuses have been fixed. {{IAST|Gaṇeśa}} holds in his two right hands the rosary and a cup filled with three modakas (a fourth substituted by the curving trunk is just about to be tasted). In his two left hands, {{IAST|Gaṇeśa}} holds a large lotus above and an axe below, with its handle leaning against his shoulder. In the {{IAST|Mudgalapurāṇa}} (VII, 70), in order to kill the demon of egotism ({{IAST|Mamāsura}}) who had attacked him, {{IAST|Gaṇeśa Vighnarāja}} throws his lotus at him. Unable to bear the fragrance of the divine flower, the demon surrenders to {{IAST|Gaṇeśa}}." </ref>]]
'''Basholi''' (Basoli) is a town in [[Kathua]] district in the state of [[Jammu and Kashmir]], [[India]]. It is situated on the right bank of River Ravi at an altitude of 1876 ft. It was founded by Raja Bhupat Pal sometime in 1635. It was known for magnificent palaces which are now in ruins and miniatures paintings (Basohli Paintings). A famous Sikh-Mughal battle [[Battle of Basoli]] was fought at Basoli.
==Geography== Basholi is located at {{coord|32.50|N|75.82|E|}}.<ref>[http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/12/Basoli.html Falling Rain Genomics, Inc - Basholi]</ref> It has an average elevation of 460 metres (1509 feet). Basoli is situated in the uneven lofty hills of Shiwaliks. It is situated in the right bank of Ravi river. Basoli has become popular for the Thein dam which has made it almost landlocked.Before the construction of Ranjit Sagar dam or Thein dam Basoli was just 32 km from Kathua but now due the dam it is about 72 km from Kathua city.
== Demographics == According to 2011 census India [[census]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.censusindia.net/results/town.php?stad=A&state5=999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040616075334/http://www.censusindia.net/results/town.php?stad=A&state5=999|archivedate=2004-06-16|title= Census of India 2001: Data from the 2001 Census, including cities, villages and towns (Provisional)|accessdate=2008-11-01|publisher= Census Commission of India}}</ref> Basohli town(urban) had a population of 5433. Males constituted 52.01% of the population and females 47.99%. Bashohli had an average literacy rate of 77%, higher than the national average of 59.5%; with 57% of the males and 43% of females literate. 12% of the population was under 6 years of age.
==Religion== Hindu 83.01%, Muslim 16.38%,<ref>http://www.census2011.co.in</ref>
== Basholi painting == Basholi is widely known for its paintings called '''Basholi paintings''', which are considered the first school of [[Pahari painting]]s, and which evolved into the much prolific [[Kangra paintings]] school by mid-eighteenth century.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=8EGUpX1O0hoC&pg=RA2-PA62&dq=Kangra+painting&as_brr=0 Pahari centres] ''Arts of India: Architecture, Sculpture, Painting, Music, Dance and Handicraft'', by Krishna Chaitanya. Published by Abhinav Publications, 1987. {{ISBN|81-7017-209-8}}. ''Page 62''.</ref> The painter [[Nainsukh]] ended his career in Basholi.
<gallery> File:Radha and Krishna in Discussion.jpg|[[Radha]] and [[Krishna]] in Discussion, (An illustration from [[Gita Govinda]]) Gouache on paper (ca.1730). File:Goddess Bhadrakali Worshipped by the Gods- from a tantric Devi series - Google Art Project.jpg|Goddess [[Bhadrakali]], adored by the Gods. Basohli. India. c 1660-70. File:Maharaja Sital Dev of Mankot in Devotion.jpg|Maharaja [[Sital Dev]] of [[Mankot]] in [[:wikt:devotion|Devotion]], Ink, opaque watercolor, and silver on paper (ca. 1690). File:Ragaputra Velavala of Bhairava.jpg|[[Ragaputra Velavala]] of [[Bhairavi (Hindustani)|Bhairava]], opaque watercolour with gold on paper (ca. 1710). </gallery>
== History == [[File:Raja Amrit Pal (Reigned 1757-1776) of Basohli LACMA M.80.223.1.jpg|thumb|Raja Amrit Pal (Reigned 1757-1776) of Basohli]] Immortalised by its artistic eminences and its connoisseur patrons, Basohli today is a metaphor for a vigorous, bold and imaginative artistic style, rich, stylish and unconventional. A style of painting characterized by vigorous use of primary colours and a peculiar facial formula prevailed in the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries in the foothills of the Western [[Himalayas]] in the [[Jammu]] and [[Punjab region|Punjab]] States. The earliest paintings in this style have been dated to the time of [[Raja Kirpal Pal]] (1678–93).A Battle was fought at Basoli, it was called as the [[Battle of Basoli]] between [[Sikhs]] and [[Mughal Empire]] in 1702.<ref name="CS">A Review of Basohli Style in Indian Painting, Chandramani Singh, Kailash - Journal of Himalayan Studies vol 2, Number 1&2, 1974 [http://www.thdl.org/texts/reprints/kailash/kailash_02_0102_reviews.pdf]</ref>
Originating in [[Basohli State]], the style spread to the Hill States of [[Mankot]], [[Nurpur State|Nurpur]], [[Kullu|Kulu]], [[Mandi State|Mandi]], [[Suket State|Suket]], [[Bilaspur (princely state)|Bilaspur]], [[Nalagarh State|Nalagarh]], [[Chamba State|Chamba]], [[Guler State|Guler]] and [[Kangra State|Kangra]]. The first mention of Basohli painting is in the annual report of the [[Archaeological Survey of India]] for the year published in 1921. Referring to the acquisitions of the Archaeological Section of the [[Lahore Museum|Central Museum]], [[Lahore]], the report states that "a series of old paintings of the Basohli School were purchased, and the Curator concludes that the Basohli Schools is possibly of pre-[[Moghul]] origin, and so called Tibeti pictures are nothing but late productions of this school".
== Places to visit ==
;Dhar Mahanpur
It is new emerging tourist spot in middle [[Himalayas]]. It is 27 km from Basohli (Tehsil HQ) and 87 km from Kathua. It is a ridge blanked with thick chir, deodhar and shrubs. It has a viewing experience is that is excellent. It experiences temperate type of climate that many visitors enjoy. It receives winter rainfall from western disturbances and summer rainfall from monsoons. Cold winter and pleasant summer are the main attractions of this place. Many Tourist Melas are organized by the Tourist Department of J&K Govt to promote tourism in the area. Tourist Huts are also proposed to be constructed. It is served by bus service available from Basohli (tehsil HQ).
;Sanan Ghat A small town on Basohli-Dhar mahanpurIt is situated at a height of 3700 ft. It is a ridge flanked with thick CHIR, DEODAR and SHRUBS. It experiences temperate type of climate . Cold winter and pleasant summer are the main attractinns of this place.
;Ranjit Sagar Dam (Thein) Hydro electric Project (Thein Dam) being constructed at the west bank of river Ravi by the Govt of Punjab and Himachal Paradesh. It as 6 turbines. It is 600 MW Hydel project. The Govt of Punjab, Himachal Paradesh and Jammu and Kashmir are the beneficiaries of this Project. Jammu & Kashmir has 20% share in this project.Prime Minister Sh Atal Behari Bajpayee has inaugurated the project . At present only one turbine is working (producing 150 MW). The Officers Colony is at Shahpur Kandi (Pathankot), 25 km from Kathua.
;Sewa Hydel Project The 120 MW Sewa-II Hydropower Station is constructed by NHPC Limited on the Sewa river, tributary of Ravi River between Gatti village (Bani Tehsil) and Maska village (Basohli Tehsil) of Kathua District.
SEWA HYDRO-ELECTRIC PROJECT was launched by Minister for Power Mr Surjit Singh Slathia at Mashka in Basohli Tehsil of Kathua District. The Project was commissioned by NHPC in July 2010 and the Power generated by this Project goes into the pool of National Grid of India. The state of J&K gets its due power share from the pool.
;Chamunda Devi Chamunda Devi Temple is located near the main chowk in Basohli town. The goddess is worshiped here in the shape of Natural rock. It is highly venerated by the people.
;Basohli Bridge A stunning cable-stayed bridge in Basohli (Jammu & Kashmir). Strategically important and first of the kind in North India and Jammu and Kashmir, the 592-meter long Basohli Bridge over River Ravi will be fourth such in the country. Out of 592 m, 350 m span is cable-stayed while the rest is plain bridge. Built at a cost of Rs 145.44 crore, Basohli Bridge is strategically very important for the quick induction of the Army during emergency. Named Atal Sethu, the bridge will also reduce the distance between Pathankot and Basohli by more than 35 km, saving both time and fuel.
[[File:Basohli bridge1.jpg|thumbnail]] [[File:Basohlibridge4.jpg|thumbnail]] [[File:Basohlibridge7.jpg|thumbnail]]

{{About|the book|the film|Belles on Their Toes (film)}} {{Infobox book | name = Belles on Their Toes | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:BellesOnTheirToes.jpg | image_size = | caption = First US edition | author = [[Ernestine Gilbreth Carey]]
[[Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr.]] | illustrator = Donald McKay | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Thomas Y. Crowell Co.|Thomas Y. Crowell]] (US)
[[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]] (UK) | pub_date = June 1950 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 237 | isbn = 0-690-13023-6 | oclc = | preceded_by = [[Cheaper by the Dozen]] | followed_by = }} '''''Belles on Their Toes''''' is a 1950 autobiographical book written by the siblings [[Frank Bunker Gilbreth, Jr.]] and [[Ernestine Gilbreth Carey]]. It is the follow-up to their book ''[[Cheaper by the Dozen]]'' (1948), which covered the period before [[Frank Gilbreth|Frank Gilbreth, Sr.]] died. It was adapted as a [[Belles on Their Toes (film)|film in 1952]]. ==Title== The title alludes both to a line in the [[nursery rhyme]] "[[Ride a cock horse to Banbury Cross]]" (i.e., "Rings on her fingers and bells on her toes") and to the marriages of the Gilbreth sisters: "It was apparent that in order to get rings on their fingers, belles would have to be on their toes."{{cite book|author=Gilbreth, Frank Bunker, Jr. |author2=Carey, Ernestine Gilbreth |last-author-amp=yes |title=Belles on Their Toes |date=1948 |page=65}} ==Synopsis== ''Belles on Their Toes'' was written about the Gilbreth family after [[Frank Bunker Gilbreth]], Sr.'s death, and how they survived as their mother, [[Lillian Moller Gilbreth]], continued the pioneering work in [[industrial engineering]], [[time and motion studies]], and industrial/organizational psychology she had shared with her husband. This book is also the first place where the absence of the second oldest child, Mary Gilbreth, is explained; she died of [[diphtheria]] in 1912, at age five. ==Film adaptation== ''[[Belles on Their Toes (film)|Belles on Their Toes]]'' was made into a 1952 motion picture starring [[Myrna Loy]] as Lillian Gilbreth. ==See also== * [[Cheaper by the Dozen (1950 film)|''Cheaper by the Dozen'' (1950 film)]] * [[Cheaper by the Dozen (2003 film)|''Cheaper by the Dozen'' (2003 film)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=0044410|title=Belles on Their Toes}} * {{cite web |title=The Gilbreths: An Extraordinary American Family |url=http://www.thegilbreths.com}}, comprehensive family and professional history. {{Gilbreth family}} [[Category:1950 books]] [[Category:American biographies]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] {{US-bio-book-stub}}

{{Expand French|Bishapour|topic=geo|date=September 2013}} {{distinguish|Nishapur}} {{Infobox ancient site |name = Bishapur |native_name = in Persian: بیشاپور |alternate_name = Bishâpûr |image = Bishapur (Iran) Sassanid Period).JPG |alt = |caption = The ruins of Bishapur |map_type = Iran |map_alt = |map_size = |coordinates = {{coord|29|46|40|N|51|34|15|E|display=inline,title}} |location = [[Kazerun]], [[Fars Province]], [[Iran]] |region = |type = Settlement |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = [[Shapur I]] |material = |built = 226 AD |abandoned = |epochs = <!-- actually displays as "Periods" --> |cultures = Persian (Sasanian era) |dependency_of = |occupants = |event = |excavations = |archaeologists = |condition = |ownership = |management = |public_access = |website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> |notes = }} '''Bishapur''' ([[Middle Persian]]: ''Bay-Šāpūr''; {{lang-fa|بیشاپور|}}, ''Bishâpûr'') was an ancient city in [[Sasanian Empire|Sasanid Persia]] ([[Iran]]) on the ancient road between [[Persis]] and [[Elam]]. The road linked the [[Sassanid]] capitals [[Estakhr]] (very close to [[Persepolis]]) and [[Ctesiphon]]. It is located south of modern [[Faliyan]] in the [[Kazerun County]] of [[Pars Province]], [[Iran]].
Bishapur was built near a river crossing and at the same site there is also a fort with rock-cut reservoirs and a river valley with six Sassanid [[rock relief]]s.
The most important point about this city, is the combination of Persian and Roman art and architecture that hadn't been seen before Bishapur construction. Before Bishapour was built, almost all the main cities in Persia/Iran had a circular shape like the old city in [[Firuzabad, Fars|Firuzabad]] or [[Darab]]. Bishapour is the first city with vertical and horizontal streets also in the city specially in interior design we can see tile work that's adapted from [[Roman art|Roman Art]]
== History == [[File:Bishapour palais Shapur.jpg|thumb|450px|upright|Ruins of Shapour Palace in Bishapur]] [[File:Bishapur by Eugène Flandin.jpg|thumb|450px|upright|Bishapur in 1840; a painting by [[Eugène Flandin]] in the book "Travel in Persia" (''Voyage en Perse'')]] [[File:Bishapour jarres.jpg|thumb|450px|upright|Jarres discovered in Bishapur]]
The name ''Bishapur'' derives from ''Bay-Šāpūr'', which means ''Lord Shapur''.<ref>http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bisapur-town</ref>
According to an inscription, the city itself was founded in 266 AD by [[Shapur I]] (241-272), who was the second Sassanid king and inflicted a triple defeat on the Romans, having killed [[Gordian III]], captured [[Valerian (emperor)|Valerian]] and forced [[Philip the Arab]] to surrender. In his native province of [[Fars Province|Fars]], he built a new capital that would measure up to his ambitions: Bishapur, ''Shapur's City''. Outside the city, Shapur decorated the sides of the Bishapur River gorge with huge historical relief commemorating his triple triumph over Rome. One of these reliefs, in a semicircular shape, has rows of registers with files of soldiers and horses, in a deliberate imitation of the narrative scenes on the [[Trajan]] column in Rome.
At Bishapur the king also inaugurated the Sassanid imagery of the king's investiture, which would be copied by his successors: the king and the god are face to face, often on horseback, and the god - usually [[Ahura Mazda]] - is holding the royal diadem out to the sovereign.
The city, has the remarkable [[Band-e Kaisar|dam bridge in Shushtar]], built by [[Roman Empire|Roman]] soldiers who had been captured after [[Battle of Edessa|Valerian's defeat]] in 260. However, it was not a completely new settlement: archaeologists have found remains from the [[Parthian Empire|Parthian]] and [[Elamite Kingdom|Elamite]] ages.
The city remained important until the [[Arab conquest of Persia]] the rise of Islam in the second quarter of the 7th century AD. There were still people living there in the 10th century.
The city has a rectangular plan with a grid pattern of regular intra urban streets, resembling [[Ancient_Roman_architecture#City_design|Roman city design]]. This design was never repeated in the [[architecture of Iran]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Salma |first1=K. Jayyusi|last2=Holod|first2=Renata|last3=Petruccioli|first3=Attilio|last4=André|first4=Raymond|title=The City in the Islamic World|date=2008|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9789004162402|page=174}}</ref>
==Excavations and Research== The site was cleared by the Russian-French archaeologist [[Roman Ghirshman]] in the 1930s. The British archaeologist [[Georgina Herrmann]] has also written a book about the Sasanian rock reliefs in Bishapur which was published in 1980.<ref>http://www.worldcat.org/title/sasanian-rock-reliefs-at-bishapur-part-1-bishapur-iii-triumph-attributed-to-shapur-i/oclc/59815517&referer=brief_results</ref>
== Decoration == [[File:Mosaic01.jpg|thumb|450px|upright|Persian-Roman floor mosaic detail from the palace of [[Shapur I]] at Bishapur. Now this tile work is in [[National Museum of Iran]]]] The main part of the excavations took place in the royal sector, in the east of the city. A water temple, interpreted as a [[Anahita|Anahita temple]] , was erected near the palace. In the center there is a cross-shaped space with eight large square exedrae decorated with 64 alcoves. The French excavators believed it had been covered with a dome roof, but this reconstruction has been rejected. To the west lies a courtyard decorated with mosaics; to the east, a square iwan used as a reception room. Its walls must have been covered with small stucco ornaments: rows of medallions, bands of foliage, and topped with merlons inherited from Achaemenid architecture. All these decorative techniques were still used after the [[Islamic conquest of Persia]].
The floor was paved with black marble slabs, with a mosaic border. Along the walls runs a narrow band featuring a series of heads and masks, in a frontal or profile view, on a white background. At the top of each alcove there was a picture of women naked under their transparent veils: courtesans, musicians, dancers, women twisting garlands, together with a few richly attired noble ladies.

[[Leslie Harris (lawyer)|Leslie Harris]] |main_organ = |num_staff = |budget = |website = {{URL|copyrightinformation.org}} }} The '''Center for Copyright Information''' ('''CCI''') is an American organization focused on advocacy and initiatives in support of copyright law. The CCI aims to educate the public about [[copyright]] law; coordinates with copyright owners and [[Internet service provider]]s (ISPs) about issues related to online [[copyright infringement]]; assists with the design, implementation, review, and promotion of an online infringement notification and mitigation system (the [[Copyright Alert System]]); collects and disseminates online infringement data; and promotes lawful means of obtaining copyrighted works.[http://www.copyrightinformation.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Memorandum-of-Understanding.pdf Memorandum of Understanding]; [http://www.copyrightinformation.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/CCI-MOU-First-Amendment.pdf Aug. 2011 amendment]; [http://www.copyrightinformation.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/CCI-MOU-Second-Amendment.pdf Oct. 2012 amendment]. The organization was created as a partnership between industry associations, including the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], the [[Recording Industry Association of America]], and five major American Internet service providers. ==Background== The Center for Copyright Information was formed in September 2011 to coordinate efforts between the television, film and music industries and service providers to curb online [[copyright infringement]] and educate Internet subscribers about the issue.{{cite web |url=http://www.copyrightinformation.org/press-release/center-for-copyright-information-announces-three-major-steps-towards-implementation/ |title=Center for Copyright Information Announces Three Major Steps Towards Implementation |date= April 2012 |work=www.copyrightinformation.org |publisher=Center for Copyright Information |accessdate=1 March 2013}} The RIAA began negotiations to create the Center for Copyright Information and its Copyright Alert System in December 2008, after it ceased a five-year litigation campaign against individual file sharers.{{cite news |title=ISPs to Disrupt Internet Access of Copyright Scofflaws |first=David |last=Kravets |url= https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/07/disrupting-internet-access/ |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate= 20 February 2013}} Between 2003 and 2008, the RIAA adopted a practice of suing individual file sharers; previously it had focused on efforts to shut down [[peer-to-peer file sharing]] services.{{cite news |title=Copyright Lawsuits Plummet in Aftermath of RIAA Campaign |first=David |last=Kravets |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/05/riaa-bump/ |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=18 May 2010 |accessdate= 20 February 2013}} The MPAA and RIAA, along with the [[Independent Film & Television Alliance]] and [[American Association of Independent Music]], as associations representing independent producers in their fields, reached an agreement in July 2011 with five large ISPs to create the Copyright Alerts System. The trade groups argued copyright infringement was costing the U.S. economy hundreds of thousands of jobs and billions of dollars in lost earnings and tax revenue annually.{{cite news |title=Internet providers to act against online pirates |first=Lisa |last=Richwine |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/07/us-internet-piracy-idUSTRE7667FL20110707 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate= 20 February 2013}} New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] helped bring parties to the table as part of his 2008 work with Internet service providers to block access to online [[child pornography]].{{cite news |title=To Slow Piracy, Internet Providers Ready Penalties |first=Ben |last=Sisario |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/08/technology/to-slow-piracy-internet-providers-ready-penalties.html?_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate= 3 March 2013}} Under the July 2011 agreement, several U.S. Internet service providers, including [[Verizon Communications]], [[Comcast]], [[Time Warner Cable]], [[Cablevision Systems]] and [[AT&T]] agreed to send alerts to customers who appeared to be using their accounts for illegal downloading.{{cite news |title=AT&T Joins Verizon in Fighting Web Piracy of Movies, Music |first=Eric |last=Engelman |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-07-07/at-t-joins-verizon-in-fight-against-web-piracy-of-movies-music.html |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate= 20 February 2013}} At the time of the agreement 75% of all broadband internet usage was provided by one of these five companies.{{cite web|last=Ernesto|title=HAS YOUR ISP JOINED THE US "SIX STRIKES" ANTI-PIRACY SCHEME?|url=http://torrentfreak.com/isp-six-strikes-anti-piracy-scheme-120803/|publisher=Torrent Freak|accessdate=6 March 2014|date=August 3, 2012}} The Memorandum of Understanding established that copyright holders and ISP’s would split the costs of the system 50/50.{{cite web|last=Ernesto|title="SIX STRIKES"COPYRIGHT ALERT SYSTEM COSTS MILLIONS|url=http://torrentfreak.com/six-strikescopyright-alert-system-costs-millions-131017/|publisher=Torrent Freak|accessdate=6 March 2014}} According to the CCI’s first tax filing, chronicling the first 8 months of the companies operations, CSA operation costs were $1,377,633.00.{{cite web|title=Center For Copyright Information Tax Return 2011|url=https://bulk.resource.org/irs.gov/eo/2013_06_EO/45-3366529_990O_201206.pdf|work=IRS Form 2011|accessdate=6 March 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307010426/https://bulk.resource.org/irs.gov/eo/2013_06_EO/45-3366529_990O_201206.pdf#|archive-date=2014-03-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} In July 2011, the [[Obama administration]] praised the formation of the CCI on the official [[White House Blog]] as "a positive step” and consistent with the executive branch’s strategy of encouraging voluntary intellectual property enforcement.{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2011/07/07/working-together-stop-internet-piracy |title=Working Together to Stop Internet Piracy |author=Victoria Espinel |date=7 July 2011 |work=www.whitehouse.gov |publisher=The White House |accessdate=20 February 2013}} In 2011, the CCI had its corporate status revoked according to the Columbia Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs for failing to file the proper paperwork, which they quickly resolved.{{cite web|last=Sam|title=US Center for Copyright Information Lost Its Title|url=http://extratorrent.cc/article/2950/us+center+for+copyright+information+lost+its+title.html|publisher=Extra Torrent|accessdate=6 March 2014}} In 2013, the CCI announced it would be supporting iKeepSafe’s pilot program. iKeepSafe, is an independently created curriculum designed to educate children about copyright law and fair use in the digital age.{{cite web|last=Mann|first=Colin|title=Six strikes’ effective in piracy fight|url=http://advanced-television.com/2014/02/26/six-strikes-effective-in-piracy-fight/|publisher=Advanced Television|accessdate=6 March 2014}} ===Leadership and advisors=== CCI is led by an executive committee, with Executive Director Jill Lesser as its head. Lesser was previously the senior vice president of domestic public policy for [[AOL]], as well as the deputy director of public policy at [[People for the American Way]].{{cite web |url=http://www.copyrightinformation.org/about-cci/ |title=About the Center for Copyright Information |work=www.copyrightinformation.org |publisher=Center for Copyright Information |accessdate=1 March 2013}} In addition, the CCI has an advisory board which "consults actively on issues the Executive Committee is considering." The CCI's original advisory board includes consumer advocates Jerry Berman, founder of the [[Center for Democracy and Technology]]; [[Gigi Sohn]], president and CEO of [[Public Knowledge]]; and Jules Polonetsky, director and co-chair of the [[Future of Privacy Forum]].{{cite news |last=Masnick |first=Mike |title=Organization Overseeing Six Strikes Agreement Between Labels And ISPs Includes Advisory Board To Try To Keep Tech Folks Happy |url=http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20120402/18015918339/organization-overseeing-six-strikes-agreement-between-labels-isps-includes-advisory-board-to-try-to-keep-tech-folks-happy.shtml |date=2 April 2012 |accessdate=1 March 2013}} Leslie Harris, former President of the Center of Democracy and Technology replaced Gigi Sohn when she was asked by the Chairman of Federal Communication’s Commission, Tom Wheeler, to run the FCC’s External Affairs branch.{{cite web|last=Tummarello|first=Kate|title='Six strikes' thwarting piracy, leader says|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/hillicon-valley/technology/199124-six-strikes-thwarting-piracy-leader-says|publisher=The Hill|accessdate=6 March 2014}} ==Copyright Alert System== {{Main|Copyright Alert System}} The Copyright Alert System uses third parties to identify when copyrighted information is shared via peer-to-peer services. These third parties inform Internet service providers, which then send an alert to the relevant customer. The Copyright Alert System was launched in February 2013 by the Center for Copyright Information.{{cite news |title=Warning System Launched for Movie, Music Pirates |first=Christopher |last=Stewart |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323699704578326402159158748 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=1 March 2013}} The CCI has stated that the primary goal of the system is "to make consumers aware of activity that has occurred using their Internet accounts, educate them on how they can prevent such activity from happening again, and provide information about the growing number of ways to access digital content legally."{{cite web |url=http://www.copyrightinformation.org/uncategorized/the-copyright-alert-system-moving-to-implementation/ |title=The Copyright Alert System: Moving to Implementation |author=Jill Lesser Espinel |work=www.copyrightinformation.org |publisher=Center for Copyright Information |accessdate=20 February 2013}} ==See also== *[[Copy protection]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://copyrightinformation.org/ Official website] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Copyright law organizations]] [[Category:Computer law]] [[Category:Motion Picture Association of America]] [[Category:Recording Industry Association of America]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2011]] [[Category:2011 establishments in the United States]]

revision.text:
[[File:Boar and Bear Hunt.jpg|thumb|''Boar and Bear Hunt'', The Devonshire Hunting Tapestries, late 1420s V&A Museum no. T.204-1957]]
The '''Devonshire Hunting Tapestries''' are a group of four magnificent [[Flanders|Flemish]] [[tapestry|tapestries]] dating from the mid-fifteenth century.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Devonshire Hunting Tapestries|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/d/devonshire-hunting-tapestries/|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=25 October 2013}}</ref> These enormous works, each over 3 metres wide, depict men and women in [[1400-1500 in fashion|fashionable dress of the early fifteenth century]] [[hunting]] in a [[forest]]. The tapestries formerly belonged to the [[Dukes of Devonshire]], but in 1957 were accepted by HM Government in lieu of tax payable on the estate of the [[10th Duke of Devonshire]] and allocated to the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], where they remain.
The [[William Cavendish, 6th Duke of Devonshire|6th Duke]] described using his 'spare' tapestry to insulate the [[Long gallery|Long Gallery]] at [[Hardwick Hall]] in the 1840s, a practice which saved these rare Gothic hangings from being discarded. The tapestries depict a ''Deer Hunt'', ''Falconry'', a ''Swan and Otter Hunt'' and a ''Boar and Bear Hunt''. The hunt was a particularly powerful theme and would have been a familiar pastime to many of the high-born individuals and families who owned tapestries. Hunting was both a stylized sport and an important source of the only meats considered noble.
This detail is from the ''Boar and Bear Hunt'' Tapestry, made in the 1420s, and shows men carrying special [[boar-spear]]s, which have cross-bars designed to stop the charge of the boar and keep its deadly [[tusk]]s at arms length. Much of the charm of these scenes lies in the elaborate costume detail. The lady crossing the stream on the lower right has 'Monte le Desire' inscribed on her flowing sleeve. This is the opening line of a popular song of the period. The practice of embellishing one's clothes with such words was a medieval equivalent of having a stylish slogan printed on a T-shirt except that, in the tapestry, weaving on a horizontal [[loom]] has reversed the letters.
The dress of the participants is of the type worn at court, particularly that of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]], which had control of the tapestry-weaving areas in the [[Burgundian Netherlands|southern Netherlands]]. It is unlikely that any serious hunting took place in such restricting and exotic clothes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Anna|title=V&A: A Hundred Highlights.|year=2001|publisher=V&A Publications|isbn=1-85177-365-7}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category|Devonshire Hunting tapestries}}
==External links== *[https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/the-devonshire-hunting-tapestries-boar-and-bear-hunt/hwFmCcIwXAxYCw?hl=en View the Tapestries] *[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1016/0304-4181%2888%2990024-3#preview "The sign of the dog: an examination of the Devonshire hunting tapestries"], Ann Claxton, ''Journal of Medieval History'', Volume 14, Issue 2, 1988
{{tapestry}} [[Category:Collections of the Victoria and Albert Museum]] [[Category:Tapestries]] [[Category:Animals in art]] [[Category:Dogs in art]] [[Category:Hunting in art]] [[Category:Pigs in art]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox flag | Name = Devon | Article = | Type = | Image = Flag of Devon.svg | Nickname = Saint Petroc's flag | Morenicks = | Use = | Symbol = | Proportion = | Adoption = October 2006 (by county council) | Design = | Designer = Ryan Sealey }} The '''Flag of Devon''' is the [[flag]] of the [[England|English]] county of [[Devon]]. It is dedicated to [[Saint Petroc]],<ref name=flag_inst> [{{Flag Institute| Devon}} The Flag Institute] <!-- The flagid in this link may need to change to track Flag institute database changes --></ref> a local saint with numerous dedications throughout Devon. It is notable for its creation through two web-based [[Opinion poll|poll]]s.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gb-e-dev.html | title=Devon, England | work = Flags of the world | date =21 October 2011 | accessdate = 28 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=bbc_devon_flag>{{Cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/devon/community_life/features/devon_flag.shtml | date = January 2005 | title = Flag celebrates Devon's heritage | publisher = BBC Devon website | accessdate = 25 January 2014}}</ref>
==History== The subject of a Devonian flag was raised by the county's contingent of scouts to the [[20th World Scout Jamboree]] in an interview on BBC Radio Devon in 2002. The scouts were unaware of a Devon flag and wondered if any of the listeners knew of a flag for the county. BBC Radio Devon took up the search for a flag for Devon and asked the public to send in designs.
The flag was created in 2003 after a vote in two polls run by the BBC Devon website, the winning design taking 49% of the votes cast. The design was created by student Ryan Sealey.<ref name=bbc_devon_flag/>
The Devon Flag is made of three colours — green ([[Pantone]] 348), black and white.<ref name=flag_inst/> Although the flag is relatively young, its colours are those traditionally identified with Devon<ref name=bbc_devon_flag/> (e.g. the colours of its [[Rugby Union]] team, [[Exeter University]] and [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.]]). [[Edward Pellew, 1st Viscount Exmouth|Lord Exmouth]] flew a dark green flag with white circles at the [[Bombardment of Algiers (1816)|Bombardment of Algiers]] (now on view at the Teign Valley Museum).{{cn|date=January 2014}} The green represents the colour of the rolling and lush Devon hills, the black represents the high and windswept moors ([[Dartmoor]] and [[Exmoor]]) and the white represents both the salt spray of Devon's two coastlines and the [[Kaolinite|China Clay]] industry (and mining in general).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.devon.gov.uk/index/councildemocracy/neighbourhoods-villages/devonflag/devonflaggroup.htm | title = Devon Flag Group | work = Devon County Council website | accessdate = 4 February 2015}}</ref>
Since its launch in 2003, the Devon Flag has gained popularity, and in October 2006 it gained "official" recognition when Devon County Council raised the flag outside County Hall.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.devon.gov.uk/devonflag | title = Devon Flag | work = Devon County Council website | accessdate = 25 January 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140201203703/http://www.devon.gov.uk/devonflag | archivedate = 1 February 2014 | df = }}</ref>
In April 2004, Rodney Lock of [[Ottery St Mary]] in [[East Devon]] was threatened with legal action for flying the Devon flag in his back garden, as he required planning permission to fly non-national flags. Since then the Minister for Housing, [[Keith Hill (politician)|Keith Hill]], has said local authorities can officially "turn a blind eye" to the practice of flying the county flag from poles.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/devon/news_features/2004/flag_blind_eye.shtml| title= Council's told they can "turn a blind eye" to flag flying | date = December 2004 | publisher = BBC Devon website | accessdate = 25 January 2014}}</ref>
==Devon Ensign==
[[File:Devon Ensign.gif|thumb|Devon Ensign]]
First flown in 2003 the Devon Regatta Ensign ''(designed by Kevin Pyne)'' adds a [[Union Jack]] into the Canton of the Devon Flag - the flag is described as for use at Regatta, High Days & Holidays, Weddings & Burials at Sea. <ref>http://imperialflags.blogspot.co.uk/2007/06/isle-of-man.html</ref> <ref>http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/gb-e-dev.html</ref>
==Flying the Devon Flag== The Devon Flag Group have suggested the following dates as days when it is appropriate for the Devon flag to be flown. Most of them are either the days of local events or the feast days of Devon's saints. It is also flown outside of these days, especially in rural towns.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.devon.gov.uk/index/councildemocracy/neighbourhoods-villages/devonflag/whentoflytheflag.htm | title = When to fly the flag | work = Devon County Council website | accessdate= 25 January 2014}}</ref>
*4 January - [[Saint Ronan|St Rumon]] of [[Tavistock, Devon|Tavistock]] and [[Romansleigh]] *7 January - [[Saint Brannock|St Brannock]] of [[Braunton]] *5 March - [[St Piran]], patron saint of tin miners *7 April - [[Saint Brannock|St Brannock]], as celebrated in [[Exeter]] *May Bank Holiday, Anniversary of first time Devon Flag Flown at [[Cornish pilot gig|World Gig Championship]] 2003, [[Isles of Scilly]] *May/June - Devon County Show *3 June - [[Kevin of Glendalough|St Kevin]] *4 June - [[St Petroc]], for whom the flag is dedicated *5 June - [[St Boniface]] of [[Crediton]] *6 June - [[St Gudwal]], hermit of Devon *17 June - [[St Nectan]], patron of [[Hartland, Devon|Hartland]] *21/22 June - [[Midsummer|Midsummers day]] *26 June - St Brannock - another feast day *8 July - [[Urith|St Urith]] *13 July - [[Juthwara|St Juthware]] *30 July - Anniversary of battle against [[Spanish Armada]] *1 August - [[Sativola|St Sidwell]], virgin of [[Exeter]] *10 August - [[Geraint|St Geraint]] of [[Dumnonia]] *30 August - [[Saint Ronan|St Rumon]] *26 September - Anniversary of [[Francis Drake|Sir Francis Drake]]'s Circumnavigation of the World *2 November - [[St Cumgar]] *5 November - [[St Kea]] *7 November - [[St Congar]] *8 December - [[St Budoc]] (St Budeaux) of [[Plymouth]] *12 December - [[St Corentin]] *21/22 December - [[Winter solstice|Midwinter]] *31 Dec to 6 Jan - [[New Year's Eve]] to [[Twelfth Night (holiday)|Twelfth Night]]
==Controversy== The creation of the flag drew criticism from [[Cornish nationalism|Cornish nationalists]], who accused it online of being an attempt to "hijack" their culture.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|title=New Flag Causes A Flap in South West| url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/devon/news_features/2003/flap_over_flag.shtml | publisher = BBC Devon website|accessdate=13 September 2008}}</ref>
Bob Burns, who started the discussion over a flag for Devon, cited the visibility of the [[Saint Piran's Flag|Cornish Flag]] as one of his reasons "Devonians are only too aware of the ubiquitous Cornish Flag, which can often be seen in the form of car bumper stickers, on vehicles entering Devon from Cornwall."<ref name=bbc_devon_flag/>
Dr Mark Stoyle, a Devon historian, noted that "People are quite aware in Devon that the Cornish make political capital by claiming to be different." He also suggested that the new-found sense of Devonian identity was a backlash against incoming "city-dwellers settling in the South West".<ref name=autogenerated1 />
The decision to dedicate the flag to St Petroc was not without controversy as the saint is equally popular in neighbouring Cornwall. But it was decided that as Devon's 27 church dedications to Saint Petroc far outweighs the 6 dedications in Cornwall, also the Devon villages named after him such as [[Petrockstowe]] and [[Newton St Petroc]], that the county had a strong claim to the saint and Cornwall had already selected [[Saint Piran]] as their patron saint many years previously.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Devon}} {{Subnational flags of the United Kingdom}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Flag Of Devon}} [[Category:Flags of places in England|Devon]] [[Category:Local government in Devon]] [[Category:Flags adopted through competition|Devon]] [[Category:Flags of saints]] [[Category:Flags with crosses|Devon]] [[Category:Flags introduced in 2006|Devon]]

'''Fondation Vincent van Gogh Arles''' is a non-profit foundation located in [[Arles]] France dedicated to the work and legacy of [[Vincent Van Gogh]]. Its goal is to generate and promote cultural and artistic activities with reference to the oeuvre of Vincent van Gogh as related to the time he spent in Arles, and the intention that van Gogh expressed in establishing an international center of artistic creation and exchange in Arles. The artistic director is editor-in-chief of [[Parkett]], [[Bice Curiger]].<ref>[http://www.fondation-vincentvangogh-arles.org/en/foundation/organization/team/ Fondation Vincent van Gogh. Team]. Retrieved 2 July 2017 </ref>
==History== In 1983 Yolande Clergue, a curator married to the photographer [[Lucien Clergue]], founded the Association for the Creation of the Fondation Van Gogh (subsequently known simply as the Fondation Van Gogh).
In 1985 Yolande Clergue proposed initiating a collection of works executed by contemporary artists in tribute to Van Gogh, including [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]]. Bacon responded enthusiastically by producing a painting specifically for the foundation. More than ninety artists chose to contribute to this homage to Vincent van Gogh.
In 2008 Yolande Clergue’s original ambition to create a Fondation Van Gogh was given new momentum by [[Luc Hoffmann]] who established a permanent framework for activities designed to preserve the memory of Van Gogh in Arles and to foster [[contemporary art]].<ref>[http://www.fondation-vincentvangogh-arles.org/en/foundation/presentation/introduction/ Fondation Vincent van Gogh. History]. Retrieved 2 July 2017</ref> This new foundation was officially established in 2010, under the name of the Fondation Vincent van Gogh Arles. It is now located in the Hôtel Léautaud de Donines.
==Foundation Board== *[[Maja Hoffmann]], chairman *[[Yvon Lambert Gallery|Yvon Lambert]], vice-chairman * Mustapha Bouhayati * Jean-Paul Capitani
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.fondation-vincentvangogh-arles.org/en/foundation/ Official website of Fondation Vincent van Gogh Arles]
[[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Art museums established in 1985]] [[Category:1985 establishments in France]]

{{redirect2|Featuring|Guest star|the astronomical term|Guest star (astronomy)|other uses|Feature (disambiguation)}} {{original research|date=April 2018}} {{use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} In [[show business]], a '''guest appearance''' is the participation of an outsider performer (such as a [[musician]] or [[actor]]) in an event such as a [[music record]] or [[concert]], [[Performance|show]], etc., when the performer does not belong to the regular cast, band or other performing group. In music, such an outside performer is often referred to as a '''guest artist'''.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Dance Encyclopedia |first1= Anatole |last1= Chujoy |first2= Phyllis Winifred |last2= Manchester |year= 1967 |publisher= [[Simon & Schuster]] |page= 434 |chapter= Guest Artist}}</ref> In [[performance art]], the terms '''guest role''' or '''guest star''' are also common, the latter term specifically indicating the guest appearance of a [[celebrity]]. The latter is often also credited as '''special guest star''' or '''special musical guest star''' by some production companies.
In [[pop music]], guest appearances are often described with the words '''featuring''', '''with''', or '''and'''. It is abbreviated in credit lists as '''feat.''', '''ft.''', '''f/''', or '''f.'''.
In a [[television series]], a guest star is an actor who appears in one or a few episodes (sometimes an entire [[story arc]]).
In [[radio]] and [[television shows]], a guest star is a guest on the show who is a celebrity.
==Classical performance arts== Guest appearances have been known in [[theatre]], [[ballet]], and [[classical music]] for centuries, with guests both from the home country and from abroad. The advent of [[air transport]] has made this practice much more practical and global.<ref name=laine>{{cite news |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E03EFD9163BF935A15754C0A967948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title= The Ballet Star as Guest Artist |first= Barry |last= Laine |authorlink=Barry Laine |work= [[The New York Times]] |date= January 7, 2008}}</ref>
In classical music, guest [[orchestra conductor]]s are a common practice.
Guest artists should not be confused with touring groups, troupes, orchestra, or even individual artists, although the distinction may be blurred. In the case of touring, their act is independent in itself, while the guest takes part in the act of the resident staff.
The duration of involvement of a guest artist may vary, from separate short-term acts with fees per concert to fixed temporary [[contract]]s for several seasons.
==Contemporary music== <!--This section is redirected to from [[Guest vocalist]].--> In the early days of the [[pop music]] industry the [[band (music)|band]]s were relatively stable units, and while guests were not uncommon, they were seldom given credits on album covers. For example, [[Eric Clapton]] was not credited in print for his guitar performance in the release of "[[While My Guitar Gently Weeps]]" of [[the Beatles]]. Still the term "featuring" was used as early as in the July 1954 [[UK Singles Chart]] by "[[The Four Aces]] featuring [[Al Alberts]]" with "[[Three Coins in the Fountain (song)|Three Coins In The Fountain]]" at 5th place.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.everyhit.com/ | title=UK Top 40 Hit Database | accessdate=July 25, 2006}}</ref> Gradually guest appearances have become a fully credited staple of music industry. The custom of guest appearance has become especially prominent in [[rap music]], and this influenced [[rock music]]ians as well.<ref name=aust>{{cite news |url= http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22799180-16947,00.html |title= Voices Find Gilt by Association |first= Mark |last= Edwards |date= November 22, 2007 |work= [[The Australian]] }}</ref>
To have a guest star on a record, the [[production coordinator]] must obtain permission from the [[record label]] of the guest and make sure that proper credits are delivered to the host record label to be printed on the album cover, often in the form "''Artist name'', courtesy of ''Record Label name.''" The permission is not always granted and sometimes negotiations may take a long time.<ref>{{cite book |first= Bobby |last= Borg |year= 2003 |title= The Musician's Handbook: A Practical Guide to Understanding the Music Business |isbn= 0-8230-8357-8}}</ref>
==Reasons for guest appearances== A common reason for guest appearances is to draw attention to an act by including a celebrity into it. And vice versa, in the fashion-driven environment of show industry, older stars keep themselves in the limelight by associating themselves with emerging stars.<ref name=aust/>
In rap, mutual and multiple guest starring was recognized as a way to diversify the performance.<ref name=aust/>
In theatre and ballet, guest appearances diversify actors' repertory and experience under different choreographers, and give more acting opportunities. Even for established stars prestigious overseas engagements increase their home status. Conversely, a guest star benefits the receiving troupe, bringing new inspiration and technique. Audience would welcome diversity, and theatrical business benefits as well: theatre connoisseurs will come to see the same piece with a new star.<ref name=laine/>
==Drawbacks== Commercialization of guests policy may also have negative consequences. Local theatres may limit the growth opportunities for their performers in favor of guests. Sometimes rehearsal times are inadequate to fully integrate the home and guest styles. Touring increases physical load on an actor. It is also associated with multiple stress factors: from [[jet lag]]s to close calls due to unanticipated travel delays.<ref name=aust/>
